questions.text: What is the most common malignancy of the GI tract?
questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract.

Tumors in the proximal colon often grow as polypoid, exophytic masses. These tumors rarely cause obstruction.

Carcinomas of the distal colon tend to be annular lesions that produce napkin-ring constrictions and luminal narrowing.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer

The risk factors for colorectal cancer are:

  • Dietary:
    • High-animal-fat diet
    • Low-fiber diet
    • Alcohol
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • FAP
    • HNPCC
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Cholecystectomy: increased right colon cancer due to exposure to bile acids
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • Smoking
  • Acromegaly
  • Pelvic irradiation

questions.text: Which of the following patients is at an increased risk of developing malignancy?

choices.text: A 40-year-old man with sessile serrated polyps

questions.solution:
Patients with sessile serrated polyps are at an increased risk of developing malignancy.

Histologically, sessile serrated polyps appear like hyperplastic polyps, but a serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands and lateral growth is the differentiating feature. They lack cytological features of dysplasia.

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in patients with juvenile polyps?
questions.solution:
The most common site of juvenile polyps is in the rectum.

Juvenile polyps are focal malformations of the epithelium and lamina propria. They may be sporadic or syndromic. They typically present with rectal bleeding in children < 5 years.

  • Sporadic juvenile polyps - solitary lesions, also called retention polyps
  • Juvenile polyposis - autosomal dominant syndrome with multiple hamartomatous polyps that have malignant potential

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal bleeding. Sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass.

The disease may be sporadic or syndromic. 

  • Sporadic juvenile polyp occurs as a single mass and is called retention polyp.
  • Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps, which may be premalignant.

Morphologically, both of these types are indistinguishable.

  • Gross appearance: They appear as pedunculated, smooth reddish lesions, and with cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic appearance: The cysts appear as dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.

Note: Complex glandular architecture and the presence of smooth muscle cutting through the lamina propria are seen in Peutz-Jeghers polyps.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following diseases have the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer?
questions.solution: Patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) have the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer. 100% of untreated patients with FAP develop colorectal carcinoma, often before the age of 30 years.

questions.text: What is the minimum number of polyps necessary for the diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires ≥100 polyps.

The current definition of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires evidence of any one of the below:

  1. Germline mutation in APC gene
  2. ≥100 colorectal adenomatous polyps (classical definition)
  3. Any colorectal adenomas < 30 years in a patient with a family history of FAP
  4. Intra-abdominal desmoid fibromatosis, osteoma of the mandible, or multiple epidermoid cysts in a patient with a family history of FAP

Colorectal adenocarcinoma develops in 100% of untreated FAP patients, often before age of 30 years and nearly always by age of 50 years.

Attenuated FAP is a less severe form of FAP with the following features:

  • Usually <100 adenomas
  • First appear usually in late childhood
  • Adenomas usually ≤1 cm until adulthood
  • Adenomas fewer and later
  • Adenomas and carcinomas 60–75% right-sided
  • The mean age of carcinoma is 55 years

The following image shows a gross specimen of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: Indirect ophthalmoscopy of an infant revealed congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. This is seen as an extraintestinal manifestation in association with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Classic FAP and Gardner's syndrome are associated with congenital retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) hypertrophy.

Congenital hypertrophy of the RPE can be generally detected at birth and is, therefore, an adjunct to the early screening of FAP.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?

choices.text: It has an autosomal recessive inheritance
Baseline colonoscopy must be done at 20 years of age
There is increased risk of ovarian and uterine cancer
It is associated with loss-of-function mutations in STK11

questions.solution:
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant syndrome.

It is commonly associated with germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11.

It is characterized by:

  • Multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps 
  • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation
  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies (including ovarian and uterine cancer)

Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy for screening are done at 20 years of age, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with complaints of chronic diarrhea, loss of weight, and hair loss. On examination, pallor, nail atrophy, and abnormal skin pigmentation were noted. On endoscopic evaluation, multiple sessile polyps were visualized in the small bowel and colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of intestinal polyps, cutaneous pigmentation, and diarrhea points toward a diagnosis of Cronkhite–Canada syndrome.

It is a non-hereditary polyposis syndrome that occurs at a mean age of 50 years.

Clinical features include:

  • Diarrhea and abdominal pain
  • Nail atrophy, hair loss, and cutaneous hyperpigmentation
  • Cachexia and anemia
  • Characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the stomach, small intestine, and colon due to abnormalities in the nonpolypoid mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following acts as the initiating mutation in the majority of sporadic colon cancers?
questions.solution:
The majority of sporadic colon tumors typically include loss of function mutation of APC gene, early in the neoplastic process (the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence).

About 10-15% of sporadic colon cancers involve the microsatellite instability pathway, which is associated with DNA mismatch repair defects (Lynch syndrome).

Related Pearl: Fearon-Vogelstein adenoma-carcinoma multistep model of colorectal neoplasia

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with hematochezia and weight loss is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The two most important prognostic factors of colorectal cancer are the depth of invasion and the presence of lymph node metastases.

The liver is the most common site of metastasis from the colon due to its portal drainage.

Related Pearl: Dukes’ staging for colorectal cancer

  • Stage A - Invasion of but not breaching the muscularis propria
  • Stage B - Breaching the muscularis propria but not involving lymph nodes
  • Stage C - Lymph nodes involved

Dukes himself never described a stage D, but this is often used to describe metastatic disease

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady has just been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma. On taking history, she revealed that both her mother and her elder sister had been diagnosed with synchronous colorectal and endometrial cancer in their forties. She should be tested for mutations in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch syndrome. She should be tested for mutations in MSH genes. 

It occurs due to defective DNA mismatch repair. It is caused by inherited mutations in genes that encode proteins responsible for the detection, excision, and repair of errors that occur during DNA replication. They include MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 or EPCAM genes.

It is the most common syndromic cause of colon cancer. It tends to occur at younger ages than sporadic colon cancers and often involves the right colon. Familial clustering of cancers occurs at several sites including:

  • Colorectum, small bowel, and stomach
  • Endometrium and ovary
  • Ureters
  • Brain
  • Hepatobiliary tract and pancreas
  • Skin

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about tumors of the appendix?

choices.text: The most common tumor is carcinoid
Goblet cell variant of carcinoid is more aggressive
Peritoneal dissemination can result in pseudomyxoma peritonei

questions.solution:
Primary adenocarcinoma of the appendix is usually of mucinous type.

Peritoneal dissemination of mucinous tumors can cause pseudomyxoma peritonei.

The most common tumor of the appendix is carcinoid tumor. This neoplasm, which is almost always benign, most frequently forms a solid bulbous swelling at the distal tip of the appendix. Goblet cell variant of carcinoid tumor is more aggressive.
